pageContext.claim: “We're going to give you a health care that’s going to cost more money than the country could make in 30 years if it does really well. That’s one year.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump knocked proposals for universal health-care, known as Medicare-for-all, but his math did not add up. The Urban Institute said for a single-payer plan similar to Sanders’ legislation found federal government spending would need to go up by $2.8 trillion next year and $34 trillion over 10 years. But federal revenues, without any changes to finance the plan, would be higher than that cost -- total federal receipts would be $3.6 trillion in 2020 and increase to $4.8 trillion by 2024.
